Authors:
Willem HP Boshoff, Alan R Wood, Botma Visser, Cornel M
Bender, Lize Joubert, Jan Richter, M. Catherine Aime, Zacharias A
Pretorius
Title:
The occurrence of the pearl millet rust, Puccinia
penicillariae, on Digitaria eriantha and Solanum species in South
Africa
Keywords:
Bitter apple; finger grass; lifecycle; nightshade;
Pucciniales; Solanaceae
Abstract:
Rust fungi are important plant pathogens and have been
extensively studied on crops and other host plants worldwide. This study
describes the heteroecious lifecycle of a rust fungus on Digitaria
eriantha (finger grass) and the Solanum species S. lichtensteinii (large
yellow bitter apple), S. campylacanthum (bitter apple) and S. melongena
(eggplant) in South Africa. Following field observations,
cross-inoculation studies involving uredinial and telial isolates
collected from Digitaria plants, as well as aeciospores from the
different Solanum species, were completed. Pennisetum glaucum (pearl
millet varieties Milkstar and Okashana, as well as 12 lines) and S.
elaeagnifolium (silverleaf nightshade or bitter apple) were resistant to
the rust isolates. Morphological descriptions and molecular phylogeny
data confirmed the identity of the rust fungus as P. penicillariae,
herein reinstated as a full species. The macrocyclic, heteroecious
lifecycle of P. penicillariae, described for the first time in South
Africa, allows for overwintering of teliospores on dormant D. eriantha
plants. Aecial sporulation on Solanum species during spring and early
summer provides inoculum from which sprouting Digitaria plants can be
infected to initiate sporothallus infection cycles.
